pathway: Pharmacy First – Acute Otitis Media (AOM) – Clinical Pathway (children and young people 1–17 years)
notes: Use shared decision-making and clinician global impression throughout.
Provide safety‑netting information for all patients and share links to evidence on antibiotics (NICE).

In infants younger than 6 months (especially <3 months) symptoms are often non-specific, coexisting systemic illness is common, and otoscopy can be technically difficult; consider lower threshold for referral.
Counsel on modifiable risk factors described by Mayo Clinic: reduce exposure to second-hand smoke, encourage breastfeeding where possible, and avoid bottle propping to limit middle-ear inflammation.
Pharmacy First scope excludes recurrent AOM (3+ episodes/6 months or 4+ episodes/12 months) and pregnant people aged under 16 years; refer these patients.

decisionTree.title: Consider the risk of deterioration or serious illness
decisionTree.question: Does the patient meet ANY high-risk or serious-illness criteria?

systemicOrSeriousIllness: Signs of a more serious illness
highRiskComorbidity: Significant heart, lung, renal, liver or neuromuscular disease
escalationAdvice: Consider calculating NEWS2 score (https://www.mdcalc.com/calc/10083/national-early-warning-score-news-2) before signposting to A&E or calling 999 for life-threatening emergencies.
suspectedAcuteComplications: Brain abscess (severe headache, confusion/irritability, muscle weakness)
redFlagSymptoms: Swelling, erythema or marked tenderness behind the ear

yes.title: Onward referral
actions: Consider NEWS2 (https://www.mdcalc.com/calc/10083/national-early-warning-score-news-2) and escalate to A&E/999 if life-threatening.
Refer to General Practice or other appropriate provider.

no.title: Patients presenting with signs and symptoms of acute otitis media
no.question: Are there acute onset symptoms suggestive of AOM?

youngerChildren: Holding, tugging or rubbing of the ear
Non-specific: fever, crying, poor feeding, restlessness, behavioural changes, cough, rhinorrhoea
riskFactors: Age 6 months–2 years when Eustachian tubes are immature
Group childcare attendance with frequent upper respiratory infections
Bottle feeding while lying down or limited breastfeeding
Seasonal viral circulation (autumn/winter) or allergy flares
Exposure to tobacco smoke or high pollution
notes: Non-specific symptoms alone do not distinguish AOM from upper respiratory tract infection.
In babies <6 months (particularly <3 months) the tympanic membrane may not be visible and coexisting systemic illness (for example bronchiolitis or bacteraemia) is more likely.

yes.title: Otoscopic examination (gateway point)
yes.question: Are otoscopic signs of AOM present?
details: Distinctly red, yellow or cloudy tympanic membrane
Moderate–severe bulging of the tympanic membrane with loss of normal landmarks and an air-fluid level behind it (indicates a middle-ear effusion)
Perforation of the tympanic membrane and/or discharge in the external auditory canal
Consider whether the appearances could be explained by other causes of middle-ear inflammation or effusion.
Features not suggestive of AOM include a tympanic membrane that is not bulging (with or without erythema/cloudiness) or an isolated air-fluid level without bulging.

yes.question: Consider topical analgesic ear drops and/or oral antibiotics?
actions: Consider phenazone 40 mg/g with lidocaine 10 mg/g ear drops (Otigo) up to 7 days, plus self-care, subject to PGD inclusion/exclusion.
If antibiotics indicated (shared decision-making) choose strategy: immediate vs back-up.

otigo_details.product: Otigo (phenazone 40 mg/g + lidocaine hydrochloride 10 mg/g) ear drops
otigo_details.indication: Local symptomatic relief of pain from AOM in children ≥1 year and <18 years with moderate–severe symptoms and pain not controlled with regular paracetamol/ibuprofen
otigo_details.dose: Instil 4 drops up to three times daily into the affected ear(s)
otigo_details.duration: Until symptoms resolve or up to 7 days
otigo_details.route: Topical into external auditory canal; warm bottle between hands before use
advice: Use PIL and Medicines for Children guidance for administration.
Consider only when PGD inclusion criteria are met and exclusions ruled out.

yes.followUp: Return to pharmacy if no improvement within 3–5 days for reassessment

no.title: Mild symptoms
actions: Offer self-care and pain relief (paracetamol/ibuprofen with age/weight-appropriate dosing).
Antibiotics are not routinely indicated; consider no prescription or a delayed prescription based on shared decision-making.
Review Mayo Clinic home care: warm compresses for short periods, keep the child upright when feeding, ensure rest/hydration, and keep the ear dry (no swimming) until symptoms resolve.
advice: Most AOM lasts ~1 week; >80% recover without antibiotics within 2–3 days from presentation.
no.followUp: Return to pharmacy if no improvement within 3–5 days for reassessment

selfCare: Analgesia: paracetamol or ibuprofen as per age/weight dosing schedules.
Adequate fluids, rest, and comfort measures.
Warm compress (or gentle heat pack) over the affected ear for short intervals for comfort (ensure not hot enough to burn).
Allow older children to rest with the head elevated or on the affected side down so the ear can drain; keep infants upright when feeding.
Limit dummy/pacifier use, avoid second-hand smoke, and maintain nasal hygiene to support Eustachian tube drainage.
education: Over 80% recover without antibiotics within 2–3 days from presentation.
Share NICE information on antibiotics and when they may (or may not) be needed.
Discuss Mayo Clinic warnings: recurrent infections can affect hearing, speech or balance; untreated infections may spread to mastoid bone or inner ear.
safetyNet: Seek medical help urgently if symptoms worsen rapidly or significantly, the child becomes very unwell, or no improvement after 2–3 days of antibiotics.
Return to community pharmacy for reassessment if no improvement within 3–5 days.

Escalate sooner if fever exceeds 39 °C (102.2 °F), drainage continues beyond 24 hours, the child has a stiff neck, severe headache, persistent vomiting, new hearing loss or facial weakness (per Mayo Clinic guidance).
